subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
According to Schuessler (2007), a loan from {{bor|zh|mkh-pro|*ɗuuk|*ɗuuk ~ *ɗuk|boat, canoe}}, whence {{cog|km|ទូក}} and {{cog|vi|nốc}} (< {{cog|mkh-vie-pro|*ɗoːk||boat}}). Foreign closed syllables having a long main vowel often correspond to open syllables in Old Chinese.

Possibly cognate of {{och-l|輈|trunk, pole}} ({{zh-ref|Schuessler, 2007}}).

Yang Xiong's ''{{w|Fangyan}}'' says that Old Chinese {{och-l|舟}} is common in central and eastern China, while its synonym {{och-l|船}} is used in western China.
